title: R45254
content: The Financial Services and General Government (FSGG) appropriations bill funds independent agencies in Title V that manage federal real property, regulate financial institutions, and oversee mail delivery. It also includes provisions on Cuba sanctions and funding for the Department of the Treasury, Executive Office of the President, judiciary, and District of Columbia. Financial regulatory agencies are funded separately from the FSGG appropriations bill. The FSGG appropriations bill focuses on funding financial services agencies, excluding financial regulatory agencies. The bill has been in its current form since 2007. Both the House and Senate FSGG bills fund the same agencies, except for the Commodity Futures Trading Commission (CFTC) which is funded through the Agriculture appropriations bill in the House and the FSGG bill in the Senate. President Trump's FY2018 budget request included approximately $3.1 billion for independent agencies funded through the FSGG bill, with $330 million allocated for the CFTC. The House Committee on Appropriations reported the Financial Services and General Government Appropriations Act, 2018, with $253 million for FSGG independent agencies and $248 million for the CFTC in the Agriculture appropriations bill. The FY2018 funding for the FSGG independent agencies in the reported bill was $253 million, with an additional $248 million for the CFTC in the Agriculture appropriations bill. The total funding of $501 million was significantly below the President's request, with most of the difference in funding for the General Services Administration. H.R. 3280 was included in H.R. 3354, which passed the House on September 14, 2017. The Senate Committee on Appropriations recommended a total funding of $593 million for the FSGG independent agencies in FY2018, with significant differences from the President's request. The recommended bill for FY2018 funding for FSGG independent agencies totaled $593 million, significantly below the President's request. Congress passed multiple continuing resolutions to provide funding based on FY2017 rates, with anomalies focusing on decreasing funding for the presidential transition. Additional funding was allocated for the GSA and SBA to address disaster costs from hurricanes in 2017. The Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2018 was enacted on March 23, 2018. The Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2018 (H.R. 1625/P.L. 115-141) was enacted on March 23, 2018, with $1.66 billion allocated for the SBA to address disaster costs from hurricanes in 2017. The bill passed in the House on March 22, 2018, and in the Senate on March 23, 2018, with additional funding for the GSA, FCC, and EAC. Total FY2018 enacted appropriations for FSGG agencies in P.L. 115-141 and P.L. 115-123 amounted to $4.7 billion, $1.6 billion above the original request. The FCC, EAC, and other agencies had significant funding differences between requested and enacted amounts. The FSGG appropriations bill funds over two dozen independent agencies with various functions. Tables show enacted amounts for FY2017, President's FY2018 request, House and Senate draft bill amounts, and combined enacted amounts from P.L. 115-141 and P.L. 115-123. The Commodity Futures Trading Commission oversees derivatives markets, including futures and swaps trading. It regulates industry personnel, prevents fraud, and protects investors. Despite the focus on financial variables, congressional jurisdiction remains with the House and Senate Agriculture Committees. Appropriations for the CFTC fall under the Agriculture Appropriations Subcommittee in the House and the Financial Services and General Government Appropriations Subcommittee in the Senate. Reforms were implemented after the 2008 financial crisis to address concerns over the largely unregulated swaps markets. The Dodd-Frank Act brought previously unregulated over-the-counter swaps markets under CFTC jurisdiction, along with futures and options markets. The CFTC now oversees swaps markets with an estimated $240 trillion notional value in the US, in addition to the $34 trillion notional value in futures and options markets. The President requested $250 million for the CFTC in FY2018, with appropriations of $249 million in P.L. 115-141. The CPSC aims to reduce consumer harm from various products. The Consumer Product Safety Commission (CPSC) received $249 million in appropriations for FY2018. The CPSC's mission is to reduce consumer harm by creating safety standards, monitoring recalls, educating consumers, and collaborating with governments. The Trump Administration requested $123 million for the CPSC in FY2018, reflecting a reduction in funding for specific programs and salaries. The CPSC's budget request for FY2018 included allocations for workforce development, product safety prevention, hazard response, and consumer communication. The House passed H.R. 3354 with $123 million for the CPSC, including $1.3 million for new VGBPSA grants. The House Appropriations Committee expected the CPSC to maintain grant funding levels from FY2017. The committee urged the CPSC to maintain FY2017 grant funding levels of $1.3 million in FY2018. Two proposed rules were advised against, one on voluntary recalls for small firms and the other on public disclosure of product hazards. The Senate draft bill allocated $123 million for the CPSC, while P.L. 115-141 provided $126 million and included a provision on recreational off-highway vehicle safety but not on blade saw injuries. The Election Assistance Commission (EAC) was established under the Help America Vote Act of 2002 to provide grant funding for election reform programs and voting machine certification. The Election Assistance Commission (EAC) was established under the Help America Vote Act of 2002 to provide funding for election reform programs and voting machine certification. The EAC's budget request for FY2018 included $9.2 million, with $1.5 million allocated to the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) for testing guidelines. The House passed H.R. 3354 with $7 million for the EAC, while the Senate draft bill proposed $9.2 million. P.L. 115-141 ultimately appropriated $10.1 million for the EAC, with $1.5 million going to NIST. The draft bill allocated $9.2 million for the Election Assistance Commission (EAC), while P.L. 115-141 provided $10.1 million directly for the EAC, with $1.5 million to be transferred to NIST. Additionally, $380 million was appropriated for improving election administration. The Federal Communications Commission (FCC) operates independently, funded by regulatory fees collected from license holders and other entities. For FY2018, the FCC requested a budget of $322 million, all from regulatory fees. The FCC requested a budget of $322 million for FY2018, derived from regulatory fees. The House and Senate bills both appropriated $322 million, with a cap for spectrum auctions. P.L. 115-141 also allocated $600 million for the TV broadcaster relocation fund. The FDIC's Office of the Inspector General received approximately $39.1 million in funding for FY2018, an increase from the previous year. The FDIC OIG received $39.1 million in FY2018, $3.2 million more than FY2017. The FEC requested $71.25 million for FY2018, $7.9 million less than FY2017. Congress appropriated the additional $7.9 million in FY2017 for the FEC's office space relocation. In FY2018, the FEC received $71.25 million, $7.9 million less than the previous year. The agency is moving to a new office space at 1050 First Street NE. The budget will mainly fund salaries, benefits, IT, and facilities expenses. Sections of the FSGG legislation include provisions related to campaign finance policy, such as prohibiting the SEC from issuing rules on political contributions and limiting trade associations' solicitation of member-companies' employees. The Federal Trade Commission (FTC) is responsible for protecting consumers from deceptive practices and promoting competition. It receives funding from direct appropriations, premerger filing fees, and Do-Not-Call Registry fees. In FY2017, the FTC had an enacted budget of $313.0 million. In FY2017, the FTC's budget totaled $313.0 million, with direct appropriations accounting for 53.3%, HSR filing fees for 41.8%, and DNC registry fees for 5.0%. The President's FY2018 request proposed a budget of $306.3 million, including cuts in salaries and expenses. H.R. 3354 passed by the House would have appropriated $306.3 million for the FTC in FY2018, with $164.3 million in direct appropriations, $126 million from HSR filing fees, and $16 million from DNC registry fees. The FTC was ordered by the House committee to submit a report on enforcing privacy laws for consumer information collected by internet service providers and online services. The Senate draft bill allocated $306.3 million for the FTC, with funding from various sources. The General Services Administration administers federal procurement policies and manages federal property and records. The General Services Administration (GSA) manages federal procurement policies, including the construction and management of federal buildings, disposal of property, and funding for former Presidents. GSA's real property activities are funded through the Federal Buildings Fund (FBF), a revolving fund used for construction, repairs, rental payments, and other building expenses. Congress sets limitations on FBF funds, and any debts can be paid using these funds. A negative total for the FBF occurs when available funds are less than expected revenue. The Federal Buildings Fund (FBF) provides funds for GSA's real property activities. The President's FY2018 request proposed $9.951 billion from the FBF, an increase of $1.106 billion from FY2017. The House-passed bill included $7.842 billion, $2.109 billion less than the President's request. The Senate draft bill also had different funding amounts. The President's FY2018 request for the Federal Buildings Fund was $9.951 billion, with the House-passed bill proposing $7.842 billion. The Senate draft bill suggested $7.809 billion. The final appropriations bill, P.L. 115-141, allocated $9.074 billion, including $511 million for GSA's operating accounts and funding for new initiatives like the Asset Proceeds and Space Management Fund and the Environmental Review Improvement Fund. The President requested $10 million for the Environmental Review Improvement Fund and $228 million for the Technology Modernization Fund. The final appropriations bill allocated $335 million for GSA's operating accounts, which was $81 million more than FY2017 and $176 million less than the President requested. The FSGG appropriations bill for FY2018 included $127 million in emergency supplemental GSA appropriations in response to recent disasters. It funds four agencies with personnel management functions: FLRA, MSPB, OPM, and OSC. FLRA administers Title VII of the FSLMRS, giving federal employees the right to join or form a union and bargain collectively. Employees have the right to join a union and bargain collectively over employment terms. Certain agencies like FBI, CIA, and NSA are excluded. FLRA resolves disputes and manages labor-related matters. The General Counsel's office conducts representation elections, investigates unfair labor practices, and manages FLRA's regional offices. The FSIP resolves labor negotiation impasses. The President requested $26.2 million for FLRA in FY2018, with 121 FTEs. The MSPB protects the civil service merit system, adjudicating appeals and federal employee complaints. The President requested $46.8 million for MSPB in FY2018, funding 235 FTEs. The MSPB requested $46.8 million for FY2018 to fund 235 FTEs, including IT infrastructure needs. The President's budget also requested $148.3 million for OPM, including funding for IT modernization and acquisition workforce capabilities. The budget requested appropriations for OPM, including funding for IT modernization and acquisition workforce capabilities. OPM requested an increase in FTE employment level for FY2018 to address critical IT infrastructure needs and maintain security posture. The budget also included funding for OIG salaries and expenses, trust fund transfers, and oversight activities. The OIG will oversee various programs at OPM, including the prescription drug audit program and IT infrastructure projects. The appropriations for OPM salaries and expenses, trust fund transfers, and OIG expenses were approved in P.L. 115-141, with some adjustments from the President's request. Additionally, H.R. 3354 required a report on OPM's actions regarding data breaches. The report accompanying H.R. 3280 directed OPM to prioritize modernizing the federal retirement process and implementing cybersecurity measures to secure sensitive information. It also required OPM to provide regular updates on progress in addressing backlogs and improving IT security practices. The House committee directed OPM to prioritize securing personally identifiable information and material related to security clearances, upgrading IT security, expediting security clearance processing, and providing biannual progress reports on the NBIB implementation plan and costs. The House committee directed OPM to focus on critical functions like recruitment and retention of the federal workforce. OPM was also instructed to reduce barriers to federal employment, improve the hiring process, and increase recruitment efforts at various institutions. Additionally, OPM was directed to report on the CyberCorps Scholarship for Service Program. The House committee directed OPM to focus on critical functions like recruitment and retention of the federal workforce, reduce barriers to federal employment, improve the hiring process, and increase recruitment efforts at various institutions. OPM was also instructed to report on the CyberCorps Scholarship for Service Program and provide resources to federal agencies when filling critical positions. Additionally, OPM was directed to report on acquisition planning and OPM cybersecurity measures in response to GAO recommendations. The House committee directed OPM to focus on critical functions like recruitment and retention of the federal workforce, reduce barriers to federal employment, improve the hiring process, and increase recruitment efforts at various institutions. OPM was also instructed to report on the CyberCorps Scholarship for Service Program and provide resources to federal agencies when filling critical positions. Additionally, OPM was directed to report on acquisition planning and OPM cybersecurity measures in response to GAO recommendations. The explanatory statement expressed the expectation that OPM "take the steps necessary to complete outstanding GAO recommendations to improve its information security." OPM Modernization —OPM is directed to continue providing reports and briefings on the status of modernization efforts and the strategic technology plan when developments and milestones occur and as future plans are determined. Retirement Backlog —OPM is directed to continue providing monthly progress reports to the House and Senate Committees on Appropriations on the retirement claims backlog. Section 619(a) (3), (4), and (5) of H.R. 3354 as passed by the House, the Senate draft bill, and P.L. 115-141 provided the mandatory appropriations for the health benefits, life insurance, and retirement accounts. According to the House Committee on Appropriations report, "These are accounts where authorizing language requires the payment of funds." The House report stated that the Congressional Budget Office (CBO) estimated $13.2 billion for the Government Payment for Annuitants, Employee Health Benefits; $48.0 million for the Government Payment for Annuitants, Employee Life Insurance; and $8.4 billion for Payment to the Civil The Office of Special Counsel (OSC) requested $26.5 million for FY2018 appropriations to safeguard federal employees from prohibited personnel practices. The agency's FTE employment level was estimated to be 144 for FY2018, with a focus on whistleblower cases and protecting employment rights. The requested funding aimed to meet rising demand for services and protect whistleblowers in various agencies. The House passed H.R. 3354 with an appropriation of $24.7 million for whistleblowers in the VA and other agencies, while the Senate and P.L. 115-141 allocated the President's requested amount. NARA, an independent agency, received $403.2 million for FY2018, with the Senate draft bill proposing $403 million and the House passing $380 million. NCUA, another independent agency, is funded by credit unions and manages the Community Development Revolving Loan. The NCUA is an independent federal agency funded by credit unions, managing the Community Development Revolving Loan Fund (CDRLF) to assist low-income credit unions. The CDRLF provides low-interest loans, deposits, and technical assistance grants for improving operations and addressing safety issues. The President requested no funding for the CDRLF in FY2018, but H.R. 3354 and P.L. 115-141 appropriated $2 million. The Office of Government Ethics (OGE) is also an independent federal agency. The Office of Government Ethics (OGE) is an independent federal agency established in 1978, responsible for financial disclosure, conflict of interest, and ethics in the executive branch. OGE's FY2018 budget was $16.4 million, with no adjudication powers but providing education and training for ethics officials. The Privacy and Civil Liberties Oversight Board (PCLOB) was reconstituted as an independent agency within the executive branch. The Privacy and Civil Liberties Oversight Board (PCLOB) was established in 2004 and reconstituted as an independent agency within the executive branch in 2007. The board ensures privacy and civil liberties are considered in anti-terrorism efforts, reviews related laws and policies, and advises the President and executive branch on these issues. The Privacy and Civil Liberties Oversight Board (PCLOB) advises the President and executive branch on privacy and civil liberties issues. The President requested $8 million for the PCLOB in FY2018, which was appropriated in P.L. 115-114. The Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (PCAOB) oversees audits of public companies and is funded through accounting support fees. Sarbanes-Oxley created a merit scholarship for accounting students. The Sarbanes-Oxley Act created a merit scholarship for accounting students funded by monetary penalties imposed by the PCAOB. The scholarship program is administered by an outside vendor under PCAOB rules. The Senate draft bill proposed allocating $1 million for these scholarships, similar to previous funding amounts. The SEC administers federal securities laws to protect investors and maintain fair trading markets. The SEC's budget is set through the normal appropriations process, with fees collected from securities exchanges offsetting its appropriations under the Dodd-Frank Act. The President's FY2018 request for the SEC was $1.85 billion, with additional funding in H.R. 3354 and the Senate draft bill. The Dodd-Frank Act also established an SEC reserve fund for long-term expenses, funded separately. The SEC has a reserve fund funded by registration fees, limited to $50 million per fiscal year and capped at $100 million. Any excess collections go to the Treasury Department. In FY2017, $25 million was rescinded from the fund, and for FY2018, the President's request and the House's proposal aimed to rescind $25 million and $75 million, respectively. The Senate draft bill did not include any rescinding of funds from the SEC reserve fund. P.L. 115-141 allocated $1.90 billion for the SEC, offset by fee collections, with $245 million designated for the headquarters lease. The Selective Service System (SSS) operates independently under the Military Selective Service Act to address emergency manpower needs. The Selective Service System (SSS) is a federal agency with the mission to serve the military's emergency manpower needs by conscripting personnel when directed by Congress and the President. Most males aged 18-25 in the US are required to register with the SSS. The draft was terminated in 1973, but standby draft registration for both men and women was approved in 1980. Funding for the SSS has remained stable in absolute dollars but decreased in inflation-adjusted terms. The President's request and legislative bills for FY2018 all included $22.9 million for the SSS. The Small Business Administration (SBA) administers programs to assist small businesses, including loan guarantees, low-interest loans for disaster victims, training programs, and advocacy. The President requested $829.1 million for the SBA in FY2018, $57.6 million less than FY2017. The request included funding for salaries, entrepreneurial development, business loan administration, disaster assistance, and other programs. The Administration requested funding for various SBA programs in FY2018, including $29.0 billion for the 7(a) loan guaranty program, $7.5 billion for the 504/CDC loan guaranty program, and $4.0 billion for the SBIC program. The House-passed bill allocated $862.8 million for the SBA, with $260.0 million for salaries and expenses and $231.1 million for entrepreneurial development. The Senate Committee on Appropriations recommended increasing Microloan intermediaries' grant funds for technical assistance to 50%. The final SBA appropriation for FY2018 was $700.8 million, with allocations for salaries, entrepreneurial development, and noncredit programs. No funding was provided for disaster assistance as it was addressed in a separate bill. The SBA received additional funding in FY2018 for disaster costs from hurricanes in 2017. The USPS generates revenue from mail users but receives appropriations for free mailing privileges. Congress authorized appropriations in the 1993 RFRA for USPS reimbursement and revenue forgone until 2035. The Postal Service Fund, established under the Postal Accountability and Enhancement Act, receives appropriations for USPS operations, USPSOIG, and PRC. The PAEA changed the appropriations process in FY2009, requiring USPSOIG and PRC to submit budget requests directly to Congress and OMB. The President requested $58.1 million for the Postal Service Fund in FY2018, an increase from FY2017. In the FY2018 budget submission, the President requested $58.1 million for the Postal Service Fund, which is $23.4 million more than the USPS's FY2017 appropriation. The President also requested $234.7 million for the USPSOIG, which is $19 million less than its FY2017 appropriation. The House-passed bill would have provided $234.7 million for USPSOIG, while the Senate draft bill would have provided $245 million. P.L. 115-141 appropriated $245 million. The House-passed bill included provisions for USPS funding and postal policy, such as maintaining six-day mail delivery, providing free mail services for overseas voting and the blind, and prohibiting fees for child support agencies. Additionally, it directed the Postmaster General to report on efforts to increase sales of the Multinational Species semipostal stamp. The House committee report directed the Postmaster General to submit a report on USPS actions to increase sales of the Multinational Species semipostal stamp. The President's FY2018 budget proposed reforms to reduce costs and improve revenue, including adjusting mail delivery frequency and rate structure. Additionally, changes to USPS's liabilities for retirement benefits were suggested. The President's FY2018 budget proposed reforms to reduce costs and improve revenue for USPS, including adjusting mail delivery frequency and rate structure. P.L. 115-141 included policy provisions from the House-passed bill and appropriated $50.7 million for the United States Tax Court in FY2018. The FSGG Appropriations Act includes general provisions applying government-wide, with new provisions proposed but not enacted for FY2018. If new budget authority exceeds the spending limit, adjustments will be made by the OMB director. The FSGG Appropriations Act includes general provisions applying government-wide, with adjustments made by the OMB director if new budget authority exceeds the spending limit. An alien authorized to work under DACA would be eligible for federal employment. The Treasury Department's OFAC administers Cuba embargo regulations, with H.R. 3280 proposing sanctions that were not included in P.L. 115-141. The provision in the FSGG Appropriations Act aimed to restrict the importation of rum and tobacco products from Cuba by authorized U.S. travelers. Another provision related to trademark sanctions on Cuba, prohibiting the authorization of licenses for marks confiscated by the Cuban government without the original owner's consent. This provision also aimed to prevent OFAC from licensing trademark registration fees in a dispute involving a Cuban company and Bacardi Limited over the Havana Club trademark. The dispute over the Havana Club trademark between a Cuban company and Bacardi Limited led to OFAC issuing a specific license for trademark renewal payments. The U.S. Patent and Trademark Office extended the Havana Club trademark until 2026. This provision was not included in the final appropriations measure for FY2017.
